clusters.title: Wednesday briefing: ‘Catastrophic’ reports as Jamaica reels from worst storm since records began
clusters.neutral_headline: Hurricane Melissa Devastates Jamaica, Heads Towards Cuba

items.title: Wednesday briefing: ‘Catastrophic’ reports as Jamaica reels from worst storm since records began
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: Meteorologists have called it ‘a dire situation unfolding in slow motion’ – what will it leave behind?Good morning. Hurricane Melissa, the strongest storm to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, made landfall at about midday local time on Tuesday. With winds reaching 185mph and torrential rains, it knocked out power lines, cut off the internet, and demolished buildings; the death toll and extent of the damage are still unknown.The storm has already hit Haiti and the Dominican Republic; though it was at one stage downgraded to a tropical storm, now it has strengthened again and is expected to arrive imminently in Cuba, where more than 700,000 people have been evacuated. “The reports that are coming in are catastrophic,” Jamaican energy and transport minister Daryl Vaz told Sky News. “Not very much survives a Category 5 hurricane, in terms of infrastructure.”Economy | Rachel Reeves has said Britain can defy gloomy economic forecasts after the fiscal watchdog infuriated ministers by predicting a productivity downgrade would leave her with a £20bn gap to fill in her forthcoming budget.Sudan | Ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are being reported from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.UK news | Downing Street has defended the prospect of paying more to house asylum seekers in disused barracks instead of hotels, arguing that quelling public disquiet was worth the extra cost. No 10 said that “communities don’t want asylum seekers housed in hotels, and neither does the government”.Middle East | Israeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Television | Prunella Scales, the actor best known for playing Sybil Fawlty in the classic comedy series Fawlty Towers, has died aged 93. Scales, who was married to fellow actor Timothy West, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease in 2013. Continue reading...
items.content: In today’s newsletter: Meteorologists have called it ‘a dire situation unfolding in slow motion’ – what will it leave behind?Good morning. Hurricane Melissa, the strongest storm to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, made landfall at about midday local time on Tuesday. With winds reaching 185mph and torrential rains, it knocked out power lines, cut off the internet, and demolished buildings; the death toll and extent of the damage are still unknown.The storm has already hit Haiti and the Dominican Republic; though it was at one stage downgraded to a tropical storm, now it has strengthened again and is expected to arrive imminently in Cuba, where more than 700,000 people have been evacuated. “The reports that are coming in are catastrophic,” Jamaican energy and transport minister Daryl Vaz told Sky News. “Not very much survives a Category 5 hurricane, in terms of infrastructure.”Economy | Rachel Reeves has said Britain can defy gloomy economic forecasts after the fiscal watchdog infuriated ministers by predicting a productivity downgrade would leave her with a £20bn gap to fill in her forthcoming budget.Sudan | Ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are being reported from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.UK news | Downing Street has defended the prospect of paying more to house asylum seekers in disused barracks instead of hotels, arguing that quelling public disquiet was worth the extra cost. No 10 said that “communities don’t want asylum seekers housed in hotels, and neither does the government”.Middle East | Israeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Television | Prunella Scales, the actor best known for playing Sybil Fawlty in the classic comedy series Fawlty Towers, has died aged 93. Scales, who was married to fellow actor Timothy West, was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease in 2013. Continue reading...

items.title: LIVE: Israel kills 90 in Gaza; Trump insists nothing will jeopardise truce
items.standfirst: Among the dead are at least 24 children as Israeli military says one of its soldiers killed.
items.content: Among the dead are at least 24 children as Israeli military says one of its soldiers killed.

items.title: Netanyahu orders Israeli army to carry out "powerful strikes" in Gaza
items.standfirst: The order from Netanyahu follows heightened tensions after Hamas returned a set of remains that Israel said belonged to a hostage recovered earlier in the war.
items.content: The order from Netanyahu follows heightened tensions after Hamas returned a set of remains that Israel said belonged to a hostage recovered earlier in the war.

items.title: Israel strikes Gaza after Netanyahu accuses Hamas of breaching ceasefire
items.standfirst: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...
items.content: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume warIsraeli warplanes struck Gaza on Tuesday night, shortly after Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, ordered the military to carry out “powerful strikes” in Gaza, in the most serious test of the increasingly shaky US-brokered ceasefire.Witnesses reported seeing Israeli planes launch strikes on Gaza City, as well as explosions across the strip shortly after Netanyahu’s announcement. At least seven people were killed in separate strikes in Gaza City and Khan Younis, including two children, medical sources said. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel launches strikes on Gaza after accusing Hamas of ceasefire violations
items.standfirst: Palestinian militants deny responsibility for Rafah attack and delays in releasing hostage remains as peace accord frays
items.content: Palestinian militants deny responsibility for Rafah attack and delays in releasing hostage remains as peace accord frays

items.title: Israeli planes strike Gaza City after Netanyahu orders 'powerful attacks'
items.standfirst: Israeli planes launched strikes on Gaza City on Tuesday after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused the militant group Hamas of violating a ceasefire in the Palestinian territory and ordered the military to carry out "powerful attacks". The Israeli strikes targeted an area close to Shifa hospital, the largest operational hospital in northern Gaza, witnesses and Hamas media said. There was no word yet on any casualties.
items.content: Israeli planes launched strikes on Gaza City on Tuesday after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused the militant group Hamas of violating a ceasefire in the Palestinian territory and ordered the military to carry out "powerful attacks". The Israeli strikes targeted an area close to Shifa hospital, the largest operational hospital in northern Gaza, witnesses and Hamas media said. There was no word yet on any casualties.

items.title: Israel launches air strikes on Gaza after accusing Hamas of violating ceasefire
items.standfirst: Israeli air strikes killed at least eleven people and wounded four in Gaza City on Tuesday. This comes as Tel Aviv accused Hamas of ceasefire violations by carrying out an attack against Israeli forces. Hamas said in a statement that it remained committed to the truce in the enclave.
items.content: Israeli air strikes killed at least eleven people and wounded four in Gaza City on Tuesday. This comes as Tel Aviv accused Hamas of ceasefire violations by carrying out an attack against Israeli forces. Hamas said in a statement that it remained committed to the truce in the enclave.

items.title: Israel says one of its soldiers killed in Gaza - as Netanyahu orders 'powerful' strikes
items.standfirst: Israel's military has said one of its troops has been killed in fighting in southern Gaza after Benjamin Netanyahu ordered new air strikes in the strip.
items.content: Israel's military has said one of its troops has been killed in fighting in southern Gaza after Benjamin Netanyahu ordered new air strikes in the strip.

ai_summary: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica as a Category 5 storm with 185 mph winds.
The storm caused widespread damage, including power outages, internet disruption, and building destruction.
Reports from Jamaica describe "catastrophic" conditions with infrastructure severely impacted.
Cuba has evacuated over 700,000 people in anticipation of the hurricane's arrival.
The storm is the strongest to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851.

clusters.title: Hurricane Melissa on brink of Cuba landfall. Maps show its forecast path.
clusters.neutral_headline: Hurricane Melissa on brink of Cuba landfall. Maps show its forecast path

items.title: Hurricane Melissa on brink of Cuba landfall. Maps show its forecast path.
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa was on the brink of making landfall over Cuba early Wednesday after bashing Jamaica as a Category 5 storm.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa was on the brink of making landfall over Cuba early Wednesday after bashing Jamaica as a Category 5 storm.

Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: ‘Storm of the century’: record-breaking Hurricane Melissa hits Jamaica and heads for Cuba
items.standfirst: Minister says parish of St Elizabeth is ‘under water’ and that families are trapped in their homes in the community of Black River in western JamaicaHurricane Melissa – latest updatesA visual guide to Jamaica’s strongest storm since 1851Tell us if you’ve been affectedHurricane Melissa is heading for Cuba after it made landfall as a category 5 storm in Jamaica, battering the country with ferocious winds, heavy flood waters and landslides as one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history.Cuba’s president warned the country was in for a “very difficult night” as the category 4 storm headed for the island’s second-largest city, Santiago de Cuba. Continue reading...

items.title: Hurricane Melissa whips Jamaica with violent winds, heavy rain before heading toward Cuba
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica as a fearsome Category 5 storm. Forecasters said it could be the island's "storm of the century."
items.content: Hurricane Melissa made landfall Tuesday in Jamaica as a fearsome Category 5 storm. Forecasters said it could be the island's "storm of the century."

items.title: Strong winds and flying debris as Hurricane Melissa makes landfall
items.standfirst: Storm surges of 13 feet (3.9m) above ground level and destructive waves are expected as the storm hits Jamaica.
items.content: Storm surges of 13 feet (3.9m) above ground level and destructive waves are expected as the storm hits Jamaica.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa batters Jamaica with catastrophic, record-breaking winds
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa made landfall on Tuesday in Jamaica as a catastrophic Category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history. Authorities urged people to seek shelter and stay indoors as a storm surge of up to 4 metres and wind speeds of 295 kph were expected across southern Jamaica.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa made landfall on Tuesday in Jamaica as a catastrophic Category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history. Authorities urged people to seek shelter and stay indoors as a storm surge of up to 4 metres and wind speeds of 295 kph were expected across southern Jamaica.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa Has Meteorologists Terrified
items.standfirst: The storm, which is set to make landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday, has stunned meteorologists with its intensity and the speed at which it built.
items.content: The storm, which is set to make landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday, has stunned meteorologists with its intensity and the speed at which it built.

ai_summary: Hurricane Melissa was nearing Cuba after battering Jamaica as a Category 5 storm.
Officials in Jamaica are preparing to assess the damage from the hurricane.
A video shows extensive destruction in Black River, near where Melissa made landfall.
Cuba's president warned of a "very difficult night" as the storm approached.
Hurricane Melissa is one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history.

items.title: The Sudanese army's last stronghold in Darfur has fallen to paramilitary forces
items.standfirst: Sudan's army has retreated from the key Darfur city of El Fasher after an 18-month siege amid reports of mass civilian deaths.
items.content: Sudan's army has retreated from the key Darfur city of El Fasher after an 18-month siege amid reports of mass civilian deaths.

items.title: Army soldiers fled key Sudanese city - leaving 200,000 civilians trapped
items.standfirst: Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) soldiers fled a key city in the hours before the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF) captured its infantry division - leaving around 200,000 civilians trapped, Sky News understands.
items.content: Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) soldiers fled a key city in the hours before the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF) captured its infantry division - leaving around 200,000 civilians trapped, Sky News understands.

items.title: Mass killings reported in Sudanese city seized by paramilitary group
items.standfirst: Rapid Support Forces accused of killing more than 2,000 unarmed civilians in El Fasher in recent daysReports of ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are emerging from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.Video released by local activists showed a fighter known for executing civilians in RSF-controlled areas shooting a group of unarmed civilians sitting on the ground at point-blank range. Continue reading...
items.content: Rapid Support Forces accused of killing more than 2,000 unarmed civilians in El Fasher in recent daysReports of ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities are emerging from El Fasher after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces took control of the city in Sudan’s western Darfur region over the weekend.Video released by local activists showed a fighter known for executing civilians in RSF-controlled areas shooting a group of unarmed civilians sitting on the ground at point-blank range. Continue reading...

items.title: Fear of mass killings as thousands trapped in besieged Sudan city taken by militia group
items.standfirst: The UN says there are credible reports of "summary executions" in el-Fasher.
items.content: The UN says there are credible reports of "summary executions" in el-Fasher.

ai_summary: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) seized control of El Fasher in Sudan's Darfur region.
Reports indicate mass killings and atrocities are occurring in the city.
The Sudanese army retreated from El Fasher after an 18-month siege.
Approximately 200,000 civilians are trapped in the besieged city.
The UN reports credible accounts of "summary executions" in El Fasher.

clusters.title: U.S. strikes 4 more alleged drug boats in Pacific, killing 14
clusters.neutral_headline: US military kills 14 in attacks on vessels in the Pacific, according to Hegseth

items.title: U.S. strikes 4 more alleged drug boats in Pacific, killing 14
items.standfirst: The U.S. on Monday struck four more vessels that the Pentagon says were trafficking narcotics in the eastern Pacific Ocean, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced.
items.content: The U.S. on Monday struck four more vessels that the Pentagon says were trafficking narcotics in the eastern Pacific Ocean, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced.

items.title: U.S. strikes four more vessels suspected of drug trafficking
items.standfirst: The U.S. military struck four more vessels that were allegedly trafficking narcotics in the eastern Pacific Ocean, killing 14 and leaving one survivor, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said. Charlie D'Agata has details.
items.content: The U.S. military struck four more vessels that were allegedly trafficking narcotics in the eastern Pacific Ocean, killing 14 and leaving one survivor, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said. Charlie D'Agata has details.

items.title: US military kills 14 in attacks on vessels in the Pacific, according to Hegseth
items.standfirst: US says one person survived latest strikes, having killed 51 people in attacks on at least 13 vessels in recent weeksThe US military killed 14 people and left one survivor in more strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in the eastern Pacific, the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, said on Monday, as the Trump administration continued to expand its campaign beyond the Caribbean.The latest strikes mean the US has now attacked at least 13 vessels and brought the officially acknowledged death toll to 51 people since the campaign began at the start of September. Continue reading...
items.content: US says one person survived latest strikes, having killed 51 people in attacks on at least 13 vessels in recent weeksThe US military killed 14 people and left one survivor in more strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in the eastern Pacific, the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, said on Monday, as the Trump administration continued to expand its campaign beyond the Caribbean.The latest strikes mean the US has now attacked at least 13 vessels and brought the officially acknowledged death toll to 51 people since the campaign began at the start of September. Continue reading...

items.title: US kills 14 in strikes on four alleged drug boats in Pacific
items.standfirst: Mexico's navy is searching for the sole survivor of the latest attack on boats the US says were carrying drugs in both the Pacific and Caribbean.
items.content: Mexico's navy is searching for the sole survivor of the latest attack on boats the US says were carrying drugs in both the Pacific and Caribbean.

items.title: US launches strikes on alleged drug-running boats off Colombia, killing 14
items.standfirst: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced Tuesday that the U.S. military has carried out three strikes in the eastern Pacific Ocean on four boats accused of carrying drugs, killing 14 people and leaving one survivor on the deadliest single day since the Trump administration began its divisive campaign against drug trafficking in the waters off South America. FRANCE 24's Caroline Baum reports.
items.content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced Tuesday that the U.S. military has carried out three strikes in the eastern Pacific Ocean on four boats accused of carrying drugs, killing 14 people and leaving one survivor on the deadliest single day since the Trump administration began its divisive campaign against drug trafficking in the waters off South America. FRANCE 24's Caroline Baum reports.

items.title: US strikes on alleged drug-running boats in eastern Pacific kill 14
items.standfirst: The US military carried out three strikes off the coast of Colombia on Monday against suspected drug-running boats, killing 14 and leaving one survivor. The death toll from the 13 disclosed strikes since early September now stands at at least 57 people.
items.content: The US military carried out three strikes off the coast of Colombia on Monday against suspected drug-running boats, killing 14 and leaving one survivor. The death toll from the 13 disclosed strikes since early September now stands at at least 57 people.

items.title: More than a dozen killed as US attacks boats in Pacific
items.standfirst: Fourteen people have died after the US launched its latest attacks on boats in the eastern Pacific Ocean, which it says were transporting illegal drugs to the country.
items.content: Fourteen people have died after the US launched its latest attacks on boats in the eastern Pacific Ocean, which it says were transporting illegal drugs to the country.

ai_summary: The US military struck four more vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean.
The strikes are part of a campaign against alleged drug trafficking.
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced the attacks.
Fourteen people were killed, and one survived the latest strikes.
The US has attacked at least 13 vessels since the campaign began.

items.title: Trump lands in South Korea amid deadlocked trade talks over $350bn deal on tariffs
items.standfirst: US president to be presented with replica royal gold crown before meeting his South Korean counterpart, Lee Jae Myung, but expectations of a breakthrough on tariffs are low Donald Trump landed in South Korea on Wednesday to meet President Lee Jae Myung, with deadlocked talks over a $350bn trade…

items.title: Trump lands in South Korea amid deadlocked trade talks over $350bn deal on tariffs
items.standfirst: US president to be presented with replica royal gold crown before meeting his South Korean counterpart, Lee Jae Myung, but expectations of a breakthrough on tariffs are lowDonald Trump landed in South Korea on Wednesday to meet President Lee Jae Myung, with deadlocked talks over a $350bn trade deal between the two countries threatening to cast a shadow over the event.After arriving on a flight from Tokyo, where he signed a rare earths deal with Japan’s new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, the US president addressed a summit of CEOs ahead of a meeting with Lee in the town of Gyeongju, a historical city playing host to the annual Apec summit. Continue reading...
items.content: US president to be presented with replica royal gold crown before meeting his South Korean counterpart, Lee Jae Myung, but expectations of a breakthrough on tariffs are lowDonald Trump landed in South Korea on Wednesday to meet President Lee Jae Myung, with deadlocked talks over a $350bn trade deal between the two countries threatening to cast a shadow over the event.After arriving on a flight from Tokyo, where he signed a rare earths deal with Japan’s new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, the US president addressed a summit of CEOs ahead of a meeting with Lee in the town of Gyeongju, a historical city playing host to the annual Apec summit. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Huge Brazilian raid on Rio gang leaves at least 64 people dead and 81 under arrest
clusters.neutral_headline: Police Raid in Rio de Janeiro Leaves Many Dead

items.title: Huge Brazilian raid on Rio gang leaves at least 64 people dead and 81 under arrest
items.standfirst: Brazilian police and soldiers launched a raid on a drug-trafficking gang in Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday, sparking shootouts that left at least 60 suspects and four police officers dead, officials said.
items.content: Brazilian police and soldiers launched a raid on a drug-trafficking gang in Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday, sparking shootouts that left at least 60 suspects and four police officers dead, officials said.(Image credit: Silvia Izquierdo)

items.title: At least 64 killed as police launch deadliest-ever raid ahead of COP30
items.standfirst: At least 64 people have been killed after police in Rio de Janeiro carried out a deadly raid days before the city hosts events linked to COP30.
items.content: At least 64 people have been killed after police in Rio de Janeiro carried out a deadly raid days before the city hosts events linked to COP30.

items.title: Police operation in Rio de Janeiro favelas leaves at least 64 people dead
items.standfirst: The raid is already being called the most lethal police action in the history of the state of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
items.content: The raid is already being called the most lethal police action in the history of the state of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

items.title: Violent police raids in Rio de Janeiro kill at least 64 people
items.standfirst: At least 64 people were killed and 81 arrested in northern Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday as police launched their biggest ever raid on the city's main drug-trafficking gang. As many as 2,500 heavily-armed officers, backed by armoured vehicles, helicopters and drones, took part in the operation.
items.content: At least 64 people were killed and 81 arrested in northern Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday as police launched their biggest ever raid on the city's main drug-trafficking gang. As many as 2,500 heavily-armed officers, backed by armoured vehicles, helicopters and drones, took part in the operation.

ai_summary: A police raid in Rio de Janeiro resulted in at least 64 deaths.
The raid targeted a drug-trafficking gang in the city.
The operation is the deadliest police action in Rio de Janeiro's history.
Over 2,500 officers, backed by vehicles and helicopters, participated.
81 people were arrested during the raid.

clusters.title: Nigerian Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka says US revoked his visa
clusters.neutral_headline: Nigerian Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka Says US Revoked Visa

items.title: Nigerian Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka says US revoked his visa
items.standfirst: The 91-year-old Nobel laureate in literature has been a critic of Trump's immigration policy.
items.content: The 91-year-old Nobel laureate in literature has been a critic of Trump's immigration policy.

items.title: Wole Soyinka, Nigerian Nobel laureate and Trump critic, says US visa revoked
items.standfirst: Soyinka, 91, who recently compared US president to Idi Amin, says ‘I have no visa – I am banned’The Trump administration has revoked the visa for Wole Soyinka, the acclaimed Nigerian Nobel prize-winning writer who has been critical of Trump since his first presidency, Soyinka revealed on Tuesday.“I want to assure the consulate … that I’m very content with the revocation of my visa,” Soyinka, who won the 1986 Nobel prize for literature, told a news conference. Continue reading...
items.content: Soyinka, 91, who recently compared US president to Idi Amin, says ‘I have no visa – I am banned’The Trump administration has revoked the visa for Wole Soyinka, the acclaimed Nigerian Nobel prize-winning writer who has been critical of Trump since his first presidency, Soyinka revealed on Tuesday.“I want to assure the consulate … that I’m very content with the revocation of my visa,” Soyinka, who won the 1986 Nobel prize for literature, told a news conference. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump administration strips Nigerian Nobel winner Wole Soyinka of US visa
items.standfirst: The first African author to win the Nobel in literature, Soyinka has been an outspoken critic of governments worldwide.
items.content: The first African author to win the Nobel in literature, Soyinka has been an outspoken critic of governments worldwide.

ai_summary: Wole Soyinka, a Nigerian Nobel laureate, says his US visa was revoked.
Soyinka has been a vocal critic of Donald Trump's policies.
He stated he is content with the revocation of his visa.
Soyinka won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1986.
The Trump administration has been criticized for its immigration policies.

items.title: North Korea fires cruise missiles ahead of Trump’s South Korea visit
items.standfirst: North Korea launched a series of sea-to-surface cruise missiles into its western waters on Tuesday, state media said, in a show of force coinciding with US President Donald Trump’s trip to South Korea for a regional summit. The tests come as Pyongyang deepens military ties with Russia and continues to reject nuclear talks with Washington.

items.title: False claims online damaged Brigitte Macron’s quality of life, daughter tells court
items.standfirst: Tiphaine Auzière spoke at trial of 10 people accused of harassment by posting claims that French first lady was born a manBrigitte Macron’s daughter has told a Paris court that false claims online that the French first lady was born a man had damaged her mother’s quality of life, leaving her worrying every day about the clothes she wears and how she stands.Tiphaine Auzière, 41, a lawyer, was called as a witness at the trial of 10 people accused of online harassment of Brigitte Macron by creating or reposting social media posts falsely claiming she was a man. Continue reading...
items.content: Tiphaine Auzière spoke at trial of 10 people accused of harassment by posting claims that French first lady was born a manBrigitte Macron’s daughter has told a Paris court that false claims online that the French first lady was born a man had damaged her mother’s quality of life, leaving her worrying every day about the clothes she wears and how she stands.Tiphaine Auzière, 41, a lawyer, was called as a witness at the trial of 10 people accused of online harassment of Brigitte Macron by creating or reposting social media posts falsely claiming she was a man. Continue reading...

items.title: Cyberbullying led to a 'deterioration' in Brigitte Macron's health, daughter says
items.standfirst: Brigitte Macron's daughter Tiphaine Auziére told a French court on Tuesday that cyberbullying had led to a "deterioration" in the French first lady's health. Auziére spoke on the second day of the trial in Paris, where 10 people are accused of amplifying rumours that her mother was assigned male at birth. French prosecutors announced earlier that day that they are seeking suspended prison terms of three months to 12 months for the defendants.
items.content: Brigitte Macron's daughter Tiphaine Auziére told a French court on Tuesday that cyberbullying had led to a "deterioration" in the French first lady's health. Auziére spoke on the second day of the trial in Paris, where 10 people are accused of amplifying rumours that her mother was assigned male at birth. French prosecutors announced earlier that day that they are seeking suspended prison terms of three months to 12 months for the defendants.

ai_summary: Brigitte Macron's daughter testified in a cyber-bullying trial.
The trial involves ten people accused of harassing Brigitte Macron.
False claims online damaged Brigitte Macron's quality of life.
The claims falsely stated Brigitte Macron was born a man.
Prosecutors are seeking prison terms for the defendants.

items.title: Publicis to Buy Singapore Meme Creator in Social Media Push
Publicis to Buy Singapore Meme Creator in Social Media Push
items.standfirst: Advertising giant Publicis Groupe SA agreed to buy Singapore’s Hepmil Media Group to bolster its social-media expertise in Southeast Asia’s rapidly growing online market.
items.content: Advertising giant Publicis Groupe SA agreed to buy Singapore’s Hepmil Media Group to bolster its social-media expertise in Southeast Asia’s rapidly growing online market.

ai_summary: Publicis Groupe SA will acquire Hepmil Media Group.
The acquisition aims to bolster social media expertise.
The deal is focused on Southeast Asia's online market.
The article highlights the growing importance of social media.
The acquisition will strengthen Publicis's digital capabilities.

clusters.title: Senate Republicans deal Trump a rare rebuke on trade with vote against Brazil tariffs
clusters.neutral_headline: Senate Republicans deal Trump a rare rebuke on trade with vote against Brazil tariffs

items.title: Senate Republicans deal Trump a rare rebuke on trade with vote against Brazil tariffs
items.standfirst: Five Republicans joined with Democrats on a vote to end the national emergency that President Trump has declared as the basis for sweeping tariffs on Brazil.
items.content: Five Republicans joined with Democrats on a vote to end the national emergency that President Trump has declared as the basis for sweeping tariffs on Brazil.(Image credit: Mario Tama)

items.title: Senate approves Democratic resolution to block Trump's tariffs on Brazil
items.standfirst: The Senate passed a measure that would block President Trump's tariffs on Brazil, after Democrats drew support from a handful of Republicans.
items.content: The Senate passed a measure that would block President Trump's tariffs on Brazil, after Democrats drew support from a handful of Republicans.

ai_summary: The Senate voted to end Trump's tariffs on Brazil.
Five Republicans joined Democrats in the vote.
The tariffs were based on a national emergency declaration.
The vote represents a rare rebuke of Trump.
The measure blocked Trump's tariffs on Brazil.

clusters.title: New Israeli strikes on Gaza threaten fragile ceasefire
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli Airstrikes in Gaza Raise Ceasefire Concerns

items.title: New Israeli strikes on Gaza threaten fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: Footage shows emergency crews rescuing civilians from rubble after Israel carried out new strikes across Gaza City.
items.content: Footage shows emergency crews rescuing civilians from rubble after Israel carried out new strikes across Gaza City.

items.title: Israel carries out airstrikes in Gaza, casting doubt on fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: The Israeli military carried out airstrikes in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, according to local health officials, throwing the tenuous U.S.-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas into question
items.content: The Israeli military carried out airstrikes in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, according to local health officials, throwing the tenuous U.S.-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas into question

ai_summary: Israeli forces conducted airstrikes in Gaza, according to local health officials.
Footage shows emergency crews rescuing civilians from rubble after the strikes.
The strikes have cast doubt on the fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.
The U.S. brokered ceasefire is now in question due to the recent actions.
New strikes were carried out across Gaza City, as reported by Al Jazeera.

clusters.title: Ivory Coast’s economic champion Ouattara consolidates power with fourth presidential term
clusters.neutral_headline: Ivory Coast President Ouattara Wins Fourth Term

items.title: Ivory Coast’s economic champion Ouattara consolidates power with fourth presidential term
items.standfirst: Ivory Coast’s Alassane Ouattara was re-elected in a landslide victory on Monday for a fourth presidential term, in a vote that was marked by the lack of credible opposition. The former high-ranking civil servant, who has led the West African country since 2011, has been both lauded for his economic success and accused of being an increasingly authoritarian leader.
items.content: Ivory Coast’s Alassane Ouattara was re-elected in a landslide victory on Monday for a fourth presidential term, in a vote that was marked by the lack of credible opposition. The former high-ranking civil servant, who has led the West African country since 2011, has been both lauded for his economic success and accused of being an increasingly authoritarian leader.

items.title: Alassane Ouattara wins landslide fourth term as Ivory Coast’s president
items.standfirst: Low turnout said to have made for most peaceful election in years, as 83-year-old accused of clampdown on dissent wins 89.77% of voteAlassane Ouattara has been declared the winner of the presidential election in Ivory Coast by a landslide.According to provisional results announced by the Independent Electoral Commission (CIE) on Monday evening, the 83-year-old won a fourth term as head of the west African country with 89.77% or 3.75m votes. Continue reading...
items.content: Low turnout said to have made for most peaceful election in years, as 83-year-old accused of clampdown on dissent wins 89.77% of voteAlassane Ouattara has been declared the winner of the presidential election in Ivory Coast by a landslide.According to provisional results announced by the Independent Electoral Commission (CIE) on Monday evening, the 83-year-old won a fourth term as head of the west African country with 89.77% or 3.75m votes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Alassane Ouattara won a fourth presidential term in Ivory Coast.
The election was marked by a lack of credible opposition.
Ouattara received 89.77% of the vote, or 3.75 million votes.
The 83-year-old has led the country since 2011.
Low turnout contributed to the most peaceful election in years.
